## HTML5 Lists: Ordered and Unordered ### Introduction HTML5 provides two types of lists: ordered and unordered. Lists are used to organize and present information in a structured manner. Ordered lists display items in a numbered sequence, while unordered lists display items with bullet points. ### Objective and Scope The objective of this documentation is to provide a comprehensive guide on how to create ordered and unordered lists in HTML5. This documentation covers the requirements, step-by-step instructions, code snippets, troubleshooting, best practices, and recommendations for creating lists in HTML5. ### Requirements and Pre-requisites To create ordered and unordered lists in HTML5, you need: - A text editor or an integrated development environment (IDE) to write HTML code. - A web browser to view the HTML file. ### Step-by-Step Instructions Follow these steps to create ordered and unordered lists in HTML5: 1. Open a text editor or IDE. 2. Create a new HTML file and save it with a .html extension. 3. Add the HTML5 doctype declaration at the beginning of the file: ```html ``` 4. Create an ordered list using the `
    ` element: ```html
    1. Item 1
    2. Item 2
    3. Item 3
    ``` 5. Create an unordered list using the `
      ` element: ```html
      • Item 1
      • Item 2
      • Item 3
      ``` 6. Save the HTML file. 7. Open the HTML file in a web browser to see the ordered and unordered lists. ### Code Snippets and Commands Here are some code snippets and commands related to creating ordered and unordered lists in HTML5: - `
        `: The opening tag for an ordered list. - `

        • `: The opening tag for a list item. ### Troubleshooting and Common Issues If the ordered or unordered list is not displaying correctly, consider the following: - Make sure the HTML file is saved with a .html extension. - Check for any syntax errors in the HTML code. - Verify that the web browser supports HTML5. ### Best Practices and Recommendations To create effective and accessible lists in HTML5, consider the following best practices: - Use ordered lists for items that need to be presented in a specific sequence. - Use unordered lists for items that don't require a specific order. - Use appropriate indentation and spacing to improve readability. - Use semantic tags, such as `
            `, `
              `, and `
            • `, to provide structure to the lists. - Use CSS to style the lists and customize the bullet points or numbering. ### Summary and Conclusion Creating ordered and unordered lists in HTML5 is a fundamental skill for web developers. By following the step-by-step instructions in this documentation, you can easily create well-structured and visually appealing lists in your HTML documents. Remember to adhere to best practices and recommendations to ensure optimal performance and accessibility.
